thread.title: Newspaper review: The £1m bomber and 'storm chaos'
thread.title_full: Newspaper review: The £1m bomber and 'storm chaos'

title: Newspaper review: The £1m bomber and 'storm chaos'
text: Messenger Image caption The Metro leads on the British Jihadi who died in a suicide bomb attack in Mosul. The paper reports that the former Guantanamo inmate was paid £1m in compensation after the UK "lobbied" for his release Image caption The Daily Mail also leads on the UK-born suicide bomber - Ronald Fiddler - who the paper says was given a "taxpayer-funded payout" to the tune of £1 million after "accusing MI6 agents of being complicit in his mistreatment by the Americans" Image caption The Times leads with remarks from Brexit secretary David Davis who on a visit to eastern Europe, reportedly said British workers would not be ready to fill jobs done by European migrants for "years and years" Image caption The Daily Telegraph reports that ministers are "set to back down" over business rates - which will soon be updated - and pay "millions" in compensation to those worst hit by the tax changes Image caption Meanwhile the Financial Times reports a warning from the chancellor Phillip Hammond, that any extra spending in next month's budget - including for business rates relief - "must be paid through higher taxes or savings elsewhere" Image caption The Sun leads on Sutton goalkeeper Wayne Shaw, who was sacked after it was revealed he told friends to place a bet on him eating a pie during Monday's live game - which the paper claims has left "fans fuming" Image caption The i reports that for many British young families, the "dream of owning a home" has faded, with "less than half" of low to middle income families on the property ladder and the UK "near the bottom" of the international table Image caption The Guardian continues its series on "the brexit gamble", leading on concerns from City bankers, that the loss of banking jobs to the EU due to Brexit could "threaten British and European financial stability" Image caption The Daily Express warns of "chaos" on the way for Britain, as Storm Doris sweeps in with 80mph gusts, "strong enough to topple trees" Image caption The Daily Mirror also carries warnings of Storm Doris which could bring with it "power cuts, travel disruption and flying debris" Image caption The Daily Star reports on an "astonishing claim" in the investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann, that the toddler went missing "while searching for her parents"
